Here's a comprehensive overview of the Azure DevOps MCP Server configuration landscape for 2025–2026:

---

## Azure DevOps MCP Server — Overview

The local Azure DevOps MCP Server is now available in public preview, letting GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code access and interact with your Azure DevOps environment, including work items, pull requests, test plans, builds, releases, and wiki pages.

Unlike cloud-based solutions that require sending your data externally, the Azure DevOps MCP Server runs locally within your secure environment, ensuring your sensitive project information never leaves your network while still delivering enterprise-grade AI capabilities.

### System Requirements

System requirements include Node.js 18.0+ and an active Azure DevOps organization.

---

## Official Microsoft MCP Server (`@azure-devops/mcp`)

### Basic VS Code Configuration

In your project, add a `.vscode/mcp.json` file that defines an input for your Azure DevOps organization name and a server using `npx -y @azure-devops/mcp` with your org as an argument.

### Nightly Builds

To stay up to date with the latest features, you can use nightly builds by updating your `mcp.json` configuration to use `@azure-devops/mcp@next`.

### Domain Filtering

To keep the toolset manageable, avoid confusing the model, and respect client limits on loaded tools, use **Domains** to load only the areas you need. Domains are named groups of related tools (e.g., core, work, work-items, repositories, wiki). Add the `-d` argument and the domain names to the server args in your `mcp.json`.

Available domains are: `core`, `work`, `work-items`, `search`, `test-plans`, `repositories`, `wiki`, `pipelines`, `advanced-security`. It is recommended to always enable `core` tools so that you can fetch project-level information.

### Copilot Instructions

It is strongly recommended to create a `.github/copilot-instructions.md` in your project to enhance the experience using the Azure DevOps MCP Server with GitHub Copilot Chat. To start, include "This project uses Azure DevOps. Always check to see if the Azure DevOps MCP server has a tool relevant to the user's request."

### On-Premises Support

Currently, the official MCP Server supports only Azure DevOps Services. Several required API endpoints are not yet available for on-premises deployments. Focusing on Azure DevOps Services during the public preview makes it easier to debug and deliver fixes.

---

## Community MCP Server (`@tiberriver256/mcp-server-azure-devops`)

There is also a community-built MCP server implementation for Azure DevOps that enables AI assistants like Claude to interact with Azure DevOps resources securely.

This server supports both **Azure Identity** and **PAT-based authentication**, and Azure DevOps Server (on-prem) requires PAT authentication.

---

## Visual Studio 2026 Integration

Azure MCP Server (Model Context Protocol) tools are now generally available out-of-the-box in Visual Studio 2026, bringing agentic cloud automation directly into the IDE.

With the integration, Visual Studio 2026 can generate Azure-related code and infrastructure definitions using natural-language prompts.

### Setup in VS 2026

Visual Studio 2026 includes Azure MCP Server tools with the Azure and AI development workload. To make them available: Open the Visual Studio Installer tool, select Modify, then on the Workloads tab select "Azure and AI development" and verify GitHub Copilot is selected.

### Configuration File Locations (Visual Studio)

Visual Studio uses `mcp.json` files checked in a specific order: `%USERPROFILE%\.mcp.json` (global), `<SOLUTIONDIR>\.vs\mcp.json` (VS-specific per user), `<SOLUTIONDIR>\.mcp.json` (solution-level, source-controllable), `<SOLUTIONDIR>\.vscode\mcp.json`, and `<SOLUTIONDIR>\.cursor\mcp.json`.

### Authentication

Azure MCP Server provides seamless authentication using Azure accounts and Microsoft Entra ID. You must first authenticate to Azure using local development tools such as the Azure CLI, Azure Developer CLI, Visual Studio, or VS Code. Azure MCP Server automatically discovers your credentials.

---

## Pricing

The Azure DevOps MCP Server is free to use. However, standard Azure DevOps pricing applies to your organization and any data access through the service. AI assistant usage might have separate costs depending on your chosen AI platform.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's a comprehensive overview of the Azure DevOps MCP Server configuration landscape for 2025–2026:

---

## Azure DevOps MCP Server — Overview

The local Azure DevOps MCP Server is now available in public preview, letting GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code access and interact with your Azure DevOps environment, including work items, pull requests, test plans, builds, releases, and wiki pages.

Unlike cloud-based solutions that require sending your data externally, the Azure DevOps MCP Server runs locally within your secure environment, ensuring your sensitive project information never leaves your network while still delivering enterprise-grade AI capabilities.

### System Requirements

System requirements include Node.js 18.0+ and an active Azure DevOps organization.

---

## Official Microsoft MCP Server (`@azure-devops/mcp`)

### Basic VS Code Configuration

In your project, add a `.vscode/mcp.json` file that defines an input for your Azure DevOps organization name and a server using `npx -y @azure-devops/mcp` with your org as an argument.

To stay up to date with the latest features, you can use nightly builds by updating your `mcp.json` configuration to use `@azure-devops/mcp@next`.

To keep the toolset manageable, avoid confusing the model, and respect client limits on loaded tools, use **Domains** to load only the areas you need. Domains are named groups of related tools (e.g., core, work, work-items, repositories, wiki). Add the `-d` argument and the domain names to the server args in your `mcp.json`.

Available domains are: `core`, `work`, `work-items`, `search`, `test-plans`, `repositories`, `wiki`, `pipelines`, `advanced-security`. It is recommended to always enable `core` tools so that you can fetch project-level information.

### Copilot Instructions

It is strongly recommended to create a `.github/copilot-instructions.md` in your project to enhance the experience using the Azure DevOps MCP Server with GitHub Copilot Chat. To start, include "This project uses Azure DevOps. Always check to see if the Azure DevOps MCP server has a tool relevant to the user's request."

Currently, the official MCP Server supports only Azure DevOps Services. Several required API endpoints are not yet available for on-premises deployments. Focusing on Azure DevOps Services during the public preview makes it easier to debug and deliver fixes.

content.thinking:
Now I have the information needed. The official Azure DevOps MCP server is `@azure-devops/mcp` and can be added to the `.vscode/mcp.json` file. Let me add it to the existing configuration.

The configuration uses `npx -y @azure-devops/mcp` with the organization name as an argument. I should ask the user for their Azure DevOps organization name, or I could use an input variable like the VS Code configuration supports.

Looking at the existing mcp.json, it has servers with "type": "http" and "type": "stdio". The Azure DevOps MCP server uses stdio with npx.


I'll set up the configuration with an input variable for the organization name so the user can provide it when they set this up.

Configuring the MCP server...

content.content:
1→{
     2→  "inputs": [
     3→    {
     4→      "id": "azdo-org",
     5→      "type": "promptString",
     6→      "description": "Azure DevOps Organization name"
     7→    }
     8→  ],
     9→  "servers": {
    10→    "github-mcp": {
    11→      "type": "http",
    12→      "url": "https://api.githubcopilot.com/mcp"
    13→    },
    14→    "nuget": {
    15→      "type": "stdio",
    16→      "command": "dnx",
    17→      "args": [
    18→        "NuGet.Mcp.Server",
    19→        "--prerelease",
    20→        "--yes"
    21→      ]
    22→    },
    23→    "microsoft.docs.mcp": {
    24→      "type": "http",
    25→      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/api/mcp"
    26→    },
    27→    "azure-devops": {
    28→      "type": "stdio",
    29→      "command": "npx",
    30→      "args": [
    31→        "-y",
    32→        "@azure-devops/mcp",
    33→        "--org",
    34→        "${input:azdo-org}"
    35→      ]
    36→    }
    37→  }
    38→}
    39→

content.text:
The Azure DevOps MCP server has been added to `.vscode/mcp.json`. Here's what was configured:

- **Server**: `@azure-devops/mcp` (official Microsoft package)
- **Type**: stdio via `npx`
- **Auth**: VS Code will prompt for your Azure DevOps organization name when the server starts. It uses Azure Identity for authentication, so make sure you're signed in via Azure CLI (`az login`) or VS Code's Azure account.
- **Prerequisite**: Node.js 18.0+ must be installed

When the server starts, it provides tools for interacting with work items, pull requests, pipelines, repositories, wikis, and more. You can optionally scope it to specific domains by adding `-d` followed by domain names (e.g., `work-items`, `repositories`, `pipelines`) to the args if you want to limit the available tools.

Sources:
- [Azure DevOps MCP Server - GitHub](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-devops-mcp)
- [Azure DevOps MCP Server Overview - Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/mcp-server/mcp-server-overview?view=azure-devops)
- [Azure DevOps MCP Server Public Preview - Azure DevOps Blog](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/devops/azure-devops-mcp-server-public-preview/)
